The animals were cramped and in its long history they were very badly treated but I think from most accounts they weren't living in little cubby holes in a sort of museum space. According to [this](https://historynavigator.org/2018/03/04/the-animals-in-the-tower-a-brief-history-of-the-royal-menagerie/) brief history, conditions were much improved towards the end. Yes, can confirm. I went on a school trip there was a child. They had weird rules and limited the colours of clothes that could be worn otherwise the animals would get upset. It was very tidy and clean.

I suspect some of the animals were either brain damaged or injured when captured as they seemed very tame and didn’t look like animals these days.

It was known as Londons first Zoo and was there for over 600 years beginning in the 1200's with Leopards , Polar bears and an Elephant.
Housing animals given to Old King's and Queens by other heads of state and explorers.
When it closed many animals were moved to the now London Zoo situated in Londons Regent Park.

>The Tower of London Menagerie did have a somewhat similar appearance to the drawing you described. The menagerie, which operated from the 1200s to 1835, housed a variety of exotic animals, including lions, a polar bear, and an elephant2. The animals were kept in relatively small, confined spaces, often in separate towers or enclosures within the Tower. Visitors could pay to see these animals, and the menagerie was a popular attraction for Londoners and visitors alike.

>The historical records and illustrations suggest that the conditions were quite cramped and not ideal for the animals, but the concept of displaying wild animals in this manner was common at the time
